document.masterDocTitle: Revision and phylogenetic analysis of the orb-weaving spider genus Glenognatha Simon, 1887 (Araneae, Tetragnathidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision and phylogenetic analysis of the orb-weaving spider genus Glenognatha Simon, 1887 (Araneae, Tetragnathidae)

materialsCitation.treatmentCitationGroup:
Pachygnatha australis
Keyserling, 1883 : 211
( syntypes from Pacasmayo , Peru , deposited in BMNH , examined through photographs of the habitus and male genitalia).

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Glenognatha australis :
Simon, 1894 : 716
;
Cabra-García et al . 2014
: 1029
, figs. 1D, 2D, 5E, 7D, 9 A –B; World Spider Catalog 2015 .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 100.
Glenognatha australis
. A–D, habitus from Peru (CAS 9039650). A, male dorsal. B, male ventral. C, female dorsal. D, female ventral. E–H, male habitus from Brazil (MCN 46671). E, dorsal. F, lateral. G, ventral. H, frontal. I–L, female habitus from Brazil (MCN 46671). I, dorsal. J, lateral. K, ventral. L, frontal. Scale bars, 200 µm. TS: tracheal spiracle.

FIGURE 101.
Glenognatha australis
. A–C, male left chelicerae (MCTP 838). A, anterior. B, posterior. C, mesal. D–F, female left chelicerae (MCN 42102). D, anterior. E, posterior. F, mesal. Scale bars, 100 µm. Prt: promarginal tooth. Ret: retromarginal tooth.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Males of
G. australis
resemble those of
G. gloriae
and
G. spherella
by the prominent Ret2 ( Figs. 101B– C ) and the absence of anterior tooth (
Fig. 101 A
). It can be distinguished from the former by the shape of the clypeus in lateral view, which is not projected ( Fig. 100F ) and from the latter by the bigger size and the uncoiled embolus tip ( Figs. 104E–F ). Females resemble those of
G . vivianae
by the bean-shaped spermathecae, but are distinguished from the latter by the enlarged Prt2 ( Fig. 101D ).
Description. Male and female described by Keyserling (1883) . Additional data.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 102.
Glenognatha australis
from Brazil. A–D, male left palp, schematic (MCTP 841). A, ventral. B, conductor, ventral. C, conductor, dorsal. D, embolus, ventral. E–H, male left palp (MCN 46671). E, ventral. F, dorsal. G, prolateral. H, retrolateral. Scale bars, 100 µm. C: conductor. CB: cymbium. CRa: conductor retrolateral apophysis. E: embolus. ED: ejaculatory duct. EMg: embolic medial groove. P: paracymbium. T: tegulum. TO: tarsal organ.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Male ( CAS 9039650)
. Habitus as in
Figures 100 A –B
. Carapace brown, darker along furrows. Sternum pale brown, darker on edges. Abdomen tan, dorsally with two diffused longitudinal black bands that join medially forming thin transverse bands in the posterior region. Venter with a median diffused black band that ramifies to the lateral surfaces from the tracheal spiracle. Silver guanine spots absent. Legs pale tan with distal parts of segments darker. Total length 2.47. Cephalothorax 1.17 long, 0.97 wide, 0.57 high. Abdomen 1.47 long, 1.20 wide, 1.12 high. Sternum 0.57 long, 0.65 wide. Eye diameters and interdistances: AME 0.10. ALE 0.09. PME 0.09. PLE 0.10.

Variation. Male total length 1.8–2.6 ( N = 10; average 2.2), cephalothorax length 1.0–1.1 ( N = 10; average 1.0), femur I length 1.0–1.6 ( N = 10; average 1.3). Female total length 2.2–3.0 ( N = 10; average 2.6), cephalothorax length 1.0–1.3 ( N = 10; average 1.1), femur I length 1.1–1.6 ( N = 10; average 1.2). Specimens from southern Brazil and Argentina exhibit a different coloration pattern ( Figs. 100E–L ).
Distribution. Known from Ecuador to northern Argentina ( Fig. 135 ).
